name: Trondheim
fun_fact: Fun fact: Trondheim was named European Region of Gastronomy 2022 and is considered Norway's food capital - it's home to the world's most northern Michelin-starred restaurants and the country's culinary university!

hero_dishes.name: Sodd
hero_dishes.description: Traditional meat soup with meatballs, served with boiled potatoes and flatbread
hero_dishes.origin_story: A TrÃ¸ndelag specialty served at celebrations, weddings, and holidays. The meatballs are seasoned with nutmeg and ginger
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants, especially during holidays and festivals

hero_dishes.name: Rakfisk
hero_dishes.description: Fermented trout, a traditional Norwegian delicacy
hero_dishes.origin_story: An ancient preservation method - fish is salted and fermented for months. Strong smell but beloved by locals

hero_dishes.name: Sveler
hero_dishes.description: Thick Norwegian pancakes, smaller and fluffier than American pancakes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Central Norway specialty, served with butter, sugar, jam, or brunost (brown cheese)
hero_dishes.where_to_find: CafÃ©s throughout Trondheim, ferry boats, mountain lodges

hero_dishes.name: Stockfish (TÃ¸rrfisk)
hero_dishes.description: Air-dried unsalted cod, preserved for months in the cold Norwegian air
hero_dishes.origin_story: Vikings traded stockfish across Europe - Trondheim was a major trading post. Rehydrated and cooked in various ways

signature_drinks.name: Karsk
signature_drinks.description: Strong coffee with moonshine or vodka - a Central Norway specialty

signature_drinks.name: Norwegian Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Trondheim has excellent microbreweries including E.C. Dahls
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At local brewpubs and bars in the warehouse district
